questions.text: Which statement regarding non-communicable diseases (NCDs) is correct?

choices.text: NCDs are responsible for the least number of deaths worldwide.
Primordial prevention of NCDs involves early diagnosis and treatment of disease.
According to the WHO, chronic NCDs have a duration of over three months
Cardiovascular diseases contribute the least to the global DALY.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) According to the WHO, chronic NCDs have a duration of over three months


Explanation: 
According to the WHO, chronic NCDs have a duration of over three months.

Non-Communicable Diseases:

  • Disability-adjusted life years (DALYs): NCDs are responsible for maximum DALY and deaths worldwide (Option A). Cardiovascular diseases contribute to maximum DALY (Option D). DALYs represent the total burden of disease, combining years of life lost due to premature death and years lived with disability from the condition.
  • Best Level of Prevention: The best level of prevention for NCDs is primordial prevention. This involves preventing the development of risk factors for NCDs (Option B). Examples of primordial prevention strategies include promoting healthy diets and physical activity from a young age to prevent obesity and associated NCDs later in life.
  • Chronic NCD Duration: The World Health Organization (WHO) defines a chronic NCD as a disease with a duration of greater than three months (Option C). This is in contrast to acute diseases, which have a shorter duration.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately reflects the healthcare services provided at various levels within the National Programme for Healthcare of the Elderly (NPHCE)?

choices.text: Sub-centers manage the treatment of minor ailments and provide rehabilitation equipment.
Primary Health Centers (PHCs) offer dedicated health clinics for the elderly three times a week.
Community Health Centers (CHCs) conduct research and development in addition to providing referral treatment.
District hospitals are responsible for training health professionals in geriatrics.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Sub-centers manage the treatment of minor ailments and provide rehabilitation equipment.


Explanation:

Center

Healthcare Services Provided

Geriatric Unit at District Hospitals

10-bed geriatric wards and dedicated outpatient department (OPD) services for geriatric patients.

Rehabilitation Units at CHCs

Dedicated health clinics for the elderly twice a week and Physiotherapy by rehabilitation workers. (Option B and C)

PHCs
  • Weekly geriatric clinics conducted by a trained Medical Officer.
  • Referrals to Community Health Centers or District Hospitals as needed.
  • Monthly clinics in villages supervised by nurses from the CHC NCD clinic.

Sub-centers
  • Domiciliary visits by ANMs (Auxiliary Nurse Midwives) and Male Health Workers
  • Treatment of minor ailments. (Option A)
  • Rehabilitation equipment. (Option A)
  • Health promotion activities like camps and interpersonal communication.
  • Opportunistic screening of the population over 30 years old using BP measurement and capillary blood glucose.

CHC NCD Clinics
  • Diagnosis and management of common CVD, diabetes, and stroke cases (outpatient and inpatient).
  • Home visits by nurses for bedridden cases.
  • Referral of complicated cases to the district hospital.

District Hospital NCD Clinic
  • Screening of individuals >30 years for diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular diseases.
  • Detailed investigations for high-risk individuals and referrals from CHCs.
  • Regular management and annual assessment of patients with cancer, diabetes, and hypertension.
  • Management of patients with established cardiovascular diseases.
  • Home-based palliative care for chronic, debilitating, and progressive patients.
  • Health education and counseling

 

 Health professionals in geriatrics are trained at the two National Centers of Ageing (NCAs) established at AIIMS, New Delhi, and Madras Medical College, Chennai (Option D).

questions.text: Which of the following is the role of an ASHA worker in the NP-NCD?

choices.text: Diagnose and initiate treatment for NCDs like diabetes and hypertension at the village level.
Perform ECGs and other lab investigations at monthly village clinics to screen for NCDs
Conduct opportunistic screenings for NCDs and refer suspected cases to community health centers.
Provide specialized care and treatment for cancer patients and refer complicated cases to district hospitals.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Conduct opportunistic screenings for NCDs and refer suspected cases to community health centers.


Explanation: 
Role of ASHA in NP-NCD:

  • Conducts opportunistic screening of the community for NCDs, including diabetes, risk factors for TB, and other NCDs
  • Uses blood pressure measurement and strip method blood glucose testing to screen individuals over 30 years old for NCDs.
  • Refers suspected cases of diabetes and hypertension to Community Health Centers (CHCs) or higher healthcare facilities for diagnosis and management.
  • Makes home visits to encourage positive behavior modifications, monitor treatment compliance, and encourage patients to attend regular check-ups for blood pressure and blood glucose at sub-centers.
  • Receives ₹10 for every Community-Based Assessment Checklist (CBAC) form completed. These forms are used to screen for NCDs, including diabetes, risk factors for TB, and other NCDs.

ASHA workers are not qualified to diagnose or initiate treatment for NCDs (Option A).

Performing ECGs and other laboratory investigations is beyond the scope of an ASHA worker's role (Option B).

They do not provide specialized cancer care or treatment (Option D).

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a target outlined in the WHO's global monitoring framework for the prevention and control of non-communicable diseases (NCDs) in India?

choices.text: A 5% relative reduction in the prevalence of insufficient physical activity by 2025.
A 25% relative reduction in premature mortality from NCDs by 2025.
A 30% relative reduction in the prevalence of current tobacco use by 2025.
An 80% availability of essential NCD medicines in public and private facilities by 2025.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A 5% relative reduction in the prevalence of insufficient physical activity by 2025.


Explanation:
Global Initiatives to Control NCDs:

  • Initiated by WHO
  • Expected to be achieved by 2025.
  • WHO framework aims for a 10% reduction in insufficient physical activity by 2025, not 15%. (Option A)

Targets are:

  1. Diabetes/Obesity 0% increase.
  2. Harmful use of alcohol- at least 10% reduction.
  3. Physical inactivity 10% reduction. (Option A)
  4. Premature mortality from NCDs 25% reduction. (Option B)
  5. Raised blood pressure by 25% reduction.
  6. Salt/ sodium intake 30% reduction.
  7. Tobacco use (Smoking) 30% reduction. (Option C)
  8. During therapy and counselling - at least 50% coverage
  9. Essential NCD medicine and technologies 80% coverage. (Option D)

Questionnaire, physical measurement, biochemical investigations are the correct sequence for conducting a non-communicable disease risk factor survey.

questions.text: Which program's logo depicts the integration of cancer control, diabetes management, cardiovascular disease prevention, and stroke management, reflecting its comprehensive approach to combating these interconnected health challenges in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)

 

Explanation:

The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-communicable Diseases (NP-NCD) is explicitly described as an integrated program. It combines efforts to address cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, and stroke, making it the most suitable program with a logo reflecting this integrated approach.

Component

Initiatives

New Initiatives under NP-NCD
  1. Intervention for prevention and control of Rheumatic Heart Disease under NP-NCD and Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK).
  2. Integration of AYUSH with NP-NCD.
  3. Integration of RNTCP with NP-NCD to articulate a national strategy for management of TB and diabetes comorbidities in India.

Cancer Component under NP-NCD

Cancer Services under NP-NCD:

  • Providing common diagnostic services, basic surgery, chemotherapy, and palliative care for cancer patients at 100 district hospitals.
  • Supporting each district with chemotherapy drugs for 100 patients, establishing day-care chemotherapy facilities, and providing facilities for laboratory investigations, including mammography.
  • Offering home-based palliative care for chronic and progressive cancer patients in 100 districts.
  • Designating State Cancer Institutes (SCIs) as apex institutions for comprehensive cancer diagnosis, treatment, and care.
  • Strengthening 45 centres as Tertiary Cancer Centres (TCCs) to deliver comprehensive cancer care services.

 

Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) logo (Option A).

questions.text: Which of the following obesity indicators is considered the most useful single measurement for assessing central obesity?

choices.text: BMI
Skinfold thickness
Waist-to-hip ratio
Waist circumference

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Waist circumference


Explanation:
Obesity can be defined as abnormal growth of adipose tissue, which may be due to an increase in fat cell size or number.

Indicators of obesity:

Body weight:

  • BMI (Quetele’s index): weight (kg) / height (m²)
  • Ponderal index: height (cm)/cube root of body weight
  • Broca’s index: height (cm) -100
  • Corpulence index: Actual weight / desirable weight
  • Lorentz formula:​​
  • Though not accurate, body weight is the most commonly used indicator of obesity
  • BMI is the most widely used indicator worldwide.
  • Does not differentiate between fat and muscle mass.
  • Also, does not provide information regarding fat distribution (Option A).

Skinfold thickness:

  • The sum of all four measurements: >40 in males and >50 in females
  • Rapid and non-invasive method for measuring body fat.
  • Measured with Harpenden skin callipers
  • Measurements taken at: mid-triceps, biceps, subscapular and suprailiac regions
  • Measures subcutaneous fat (Option B)

Waist circumference:

  • >102 cm in males and >88 cm in females
  • In the Indian population, >90 cm in males and >80 cm in females is considered high risk.
  • Measured at midpoint between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest.
  • Correlates closely with BMI
  • Most commonly used to measure central obesity and its associated risk factors (Option C)
  • Directly related to cardiovascular and other chronic diseases

Waist to hip ratio

  • >1 in men and >0.85 in females
  • Correlates with waist circumference
  • There may be some discrepancies as the body fat distribution may be different for each individual (Option D)

questions.text:
Match the following research trials/programs with their respective objectives:


	
		
			
			i) MRFIT
			
			
			a. Surveillance and assessment of trends in cardiovascular events
			
		
		
			
			ii) Jai vigyan mission
			
			
			b. Decreasing serum cholesterol, diastolic BP, smoking cessation in lowering coronary heart disease mortality
			
		
		
			
			iii) MONICA
			
			
			c. Dietary approaches to stop HTN
			
		
		
			
			iv) MPOWER
			
			
			d. To control rheumatic heart disease
			
		
		
			
			v) DASH
			
			
			e. To control consumption of Tobacco

choices.text: i-d, ii-a, iii-b, iv-e, v-c
i-c, ii-e, iii-a, iv-d, v-b
i-b, ii-d, iii-a, iv-e, v-c
i-a, ii-c, iii-b, iv-e, v-d

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) i-b, ii-d, iii-a, iv-e, v-c


Explanation:

Multiple risk factor intervention Trial (MRFIT)
  • It is a randomised, primary prevention trial
  • Its objective is to check whether decreasing high levels of serum cholesterol, DBP and smoking cessation would help in reducing coronary heart disease mortality.

MPOWER
  • Monitor tobacco use and prevention policies
  • Protect people from use of tobacco
  • Offer help for quitting tobacco use
  • Warn about the dangers with tobacco use
  • Enforce bans on tobacco advertising, promotion and sponsorship
  • Raise taxes on tobacco

MONICA
  • Monitoring trends and determinants in cardiovascular disease
  • Surveillance and assessment in trends of cardiovascular disease

Dietary approaches to stop hypertension

(DASH)
  • Consume a diet rich in vegetables, fruits and low fat dairy products with low content of saturated and total fats
  • Helps in decreasing around 8-14 mm hg of SBP

Jai Vigyan mission
  • Surveillance for finding out epidemiological determinants for Group A strep and sore throat.
  • Establishment of registry of RHD/RF all over the country
  • To promote vaccine development
  • To promote research and studies for investigations of RHD/RF

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding diabetes mellitus?

choices.text: Fasting plasma glucose should be ≥6 mmol/L
2 hour post load capillary plasma glucose should be ≥200 mg/dL
Random plasma glucose should be ≥11.1 mmol/L
HbA1c should be >6%

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Random plasma glucose should be ≥11.1 mmol/L


Explanation:
Diabetes mellitus is a metabolic disorder identified by the presence of hyperglycemia in the absence of treatment.

Diagnostic criteria for DM:

According to WHO

Measurement

Diagnostic cut-off value

≥7 mmol/L (126 mg/dL) (Option A)

≥11.1 mol/L (200 mg/dL)

2 hour post load capillary plasma glucose

≥12.2 mmol/L (220 mg/dL) (Option B)

Random plasma glucose

≥11.1 mmol/L (200 mg/dL) (Option C)

HbA1c

≥6.5% (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding HTN?

choices.text: A BP of 146/92 is considered a Grade I HTN.
On tracking of HTN, a person who is hypotensive in childhood then remains hypotensive in adulthood.
Only half of all hypertensive patients need lifelong medication; others manage with lifestyle changes alone.
Weight loss is the single most beneficial lifestyle modification done to manage HTN.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Only half of all hypertensive patients need lifelong medication; others manage with lifestyle changes alone.


Explanation:
Hypertension is a chronic condition defined as an increase in blood pressure.

Tracking of Hypertension:

  • If blood pressure is tracked from childhood over a period of years, then hypotensive children tend to remain hypotensive in adulthood, and hypertensive children tend to remain hypertensive in adulthood (Option B).
  • This phenomenon is useful in identifying at-risk children and planning for adequate management of HTN.

Rules of Halves (Option C):

The concept of the "Rule of Halves" in hypertension management illustrates that:

  • Approximately 50% of individuals with hypertension are aware of their condition.
  • Among those aware, only about 50% receive treatment.
  • Out of those receiving treatment, approximately 50% have their blood pressure adequately controlled.

questions.text: According to the Global Cancer Observatory, what type of cancer is most common worldwide i its designated ribbon colour?

choices.text: Lung Cancer & Dark Blue Ribbon
Breast Cancer & Pink Ribbon
Lung Cancer & White Ribbon
Colon Cancer & Dark Blue Ribbon

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Breast Cancer and Pink Ribbon


Explanation:

According to the Global Cancer Observatory (GLOBOCAN),

Most common cancer worldwide (Both Genders):

  1. Absolute numbers, Incidence, Both sexes, in 2022 (World Wide)- Lung Cancer.
  2. Age-Standardized Rate (World) per 100 000, Incidence, Both sexes, in 2022- Breast Cancer.

Most common cancer in India in terms of absolute numbers, incidence:

  1. Lip/Oral Cancer in Males
  2. Breast cancer in females

According to the National Cancer Registry, the most common cause of cancer in

  1. Males in India – Lung cancer.
  2. Females in India - Breast cancer.
